Some, who saw at a distance, fixed their eyes on Vespasian, and the.armies in the East. They foresaw new commotions in that part of the world, and dreaded the calamities of another war. Vespasian, they agreed, was in every respect superior to the two chiefs, who now convulsed the state; but even his character (b) was rather proble- matical. The truth is, of all the princes, who to his time reigned at Rome, he was the only one, whom power reformed, and made a better man. LI.
